summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment against Rakeem Davis, Jr., a convicted felon who was sentenced to prison for possession of a Browning 9mm handgun and ten rounds of 9mm ammunition on July 29, 2017.  The court granted Davis’s request for a temporary restraining order and ordered him to surrender his firearm and ammunition.  Davis consented, without admitting or denying the allegations in the motion, to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from future violations of the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders him to pay a civil penalty of $150,000.  In a separate administrative proceeding, the court denied Davis a motion to withdraw from the case.  According to the court, Davis, who was previously convicted of the same felony, had agreed to settle the case by consenting to a permanent injunction and to a five-year conduct-based injunction prohibiting him from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any firearm, ammunition, or other emergency relief.  He also agreed to be barred from serving as an officer or director of a public company for five years and ordered to pay $75,000 in disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and a civil monetary penalty equal to the amount of his civil penalty.  On August 2, 2019, the Honorable Paul G. Sansone of the United States District Court in New York entered a judgment against Davis, ordering him to disgorge his ill-gotten gains plus interest, imposing a $50,000 civil penalty, and appointing a new attorney.  Without admitting to the SEC's findings, Davis has consented to permanent injunctions against future violations, a conduct-related injunction, and an officer-and-director bar against him from appearing or practicing before the SEC as an attorney. The court also granted Davis the right to a hearing in which he will be sentenced based on the facts of the case, without requiring him to show cause or consent to the appointment of a new lawyer, and with respect to his prior conviction for the same conduct alleged in the complaint.  At the hearing, Davis also told the court that he did not object to the issuance of the injunction, that he had reviewed the evidence, that there was no conflict or breakdown in communication between the defendant and his counsel, and that he was not prejudiced by counsel's continued representation during trial.  As a result of this conduct, Davis was not required to submit a written opinion in support of his motion to be permanently enjoined from violating the charged provisions of the federal securities laws.
